questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer

options.label: C
options.text: Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV

options.label: D
options.text: Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.correct_answer: C. Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The non-contraceptive benefits of combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) include:
  • • Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer : COCPs reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer. Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer : COCPs lower the incidence of endometrial malignancy. Reduction in the incidence of ectopic pregnancy : COCPs decrease the likelihood of ectopic pregnancies by preventing ovulation and thickening cervical mucus.
  • • Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer : COCPs reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.
  • • Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
  • • Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer : COCPs lower the incidence of endometrial malignancy.
  • • Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer
  • • Reduction in the incidence of ectopic pregnancy : COCPs decrease the likelihood of ectopic pregnancies by preventing ovulation and thickening cervical mucus.
  • • Reduction in the incidence of ectopic pregnancy
  • • However, COCPs do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer : COCPs are known to reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.
  • • Option A. Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
  • • Option B. Ectopic pregnancy : COCPs lower the risk of ectopic pregnancy by preventing ovulation and thickening the cervical mucus.
  • • Option B. Ectopic pregnancy
  • • Option D. Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer : COCPs decrease the risk of endometrial cancer.
  • • Option D. Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Combined oral contraceptive pills do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg 124, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 489

questions.text: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above which you perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 4 mm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Post menopausal bleeding with a finding of endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm (5 mm or more) requires further evaluation, i.e., a biopsy of the endometrium. If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm, then malignancy is unlikely and the likely cause of bleeding being endometrial atrophy and there is no need of a biopsy. The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is atrophic endometritis
  • • Post menopausal bleeding with a finding of endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm (5 mm or more) requires further evaluation, i.e., a biopsy of the endometrium.
  • • If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm, then malignancy is unlikely and the likely cause of bleeding being endometrial atrophy and there is no need of a biopsy.
  • • The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is atrophic endometritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In postmenopausal women with bleeding, an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm on transvaginal ultrasonography should prompt further evaluation with an endometrial biopsy to rule out malignancy or other significant pathology.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg 186, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 357
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg 186, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 357

questions.text: Drug of choice for malaria (plasmodium vivax) in pregnancy? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chloroquine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy
  • ➤ Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy
  • ➤ Chloroquine – 600 mg base P.O. followed by 300 mg 12 hours later. Then 300 mg daily for next 2 days. To prevent relapse during pregnancy, 300 mg is to be taken weekly until delivery. For radical cure, primaquine should be postponed until pregnancy is over. Parasites resistant to chloroquine should be given quinine under supervision. Patients with severe anemia may need blood transfusion. Folic acid 10 mg should be given daily to prevent megaloblastic anemia. Complicated malaria: Artesunate IV 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12 and 24 hours, then daily thereafter. Oral therapy (2 mg/kg) is started when the patient is stable. Alternatively, Quinine IV followed by oral therapy is given.
  • ➤ Chloroquine – 600 mg base P.O. followed by 300 mg 12 hours later. Then 300 mg daily for next 2 days.
  • ➤ To prevent relapse during pregnancy, 300 mg is to be taken weekly until delivery.
  • ➤ For radical cure, primaquine should be postponed until pregnancy is over.
  • ➤ Parasites resistant to chloroquine should be given quinine under supervision.
  • ➤ Patients with severe anemia may need blood transfusion.
  • ➤ Folic acid 10 mg should be given daily to prevent megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to you with complaints of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back and feels relieved if she lies on her side or when walks. What is the most likely reason behind this? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IVC compression

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The symptoms of light-headedness and dizziness that the pregnant woman experiences when lying on her back, which are relieved by lying on her side or walking, are indicative of inferior vena cava (IVC) compression. In the supine position during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the IVC, which can decrease venous return to the heart. This condition, known as supine hypotensive syndrome, leads to reduced cardiac output and can cause symptoms such as dizziness, light-headedness, and a decreased supply of oxygen and nutrients to vital organs.
  • • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: This occurs when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart, leading to symptoms like dizziness and light-headedness. Relief by changing position: Symptoms are relieved when the woman lies on her side or walks because these positions alleviate the pressure on the IVC, improving venous return and cardiac output.
  • • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: This occurs when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart, leading to symptoms like dizziness and light-headedness.
  • • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome:
  • • Relief by changing position: Symptoms are relieved when the woman lies on her side or walks because these positions alleviate the pressure on the IVC, improving venous return and cardiac output.
  • • Relief by changing position:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Increased intracranial pressure: This would present with symptoms such as headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, and altered mental status, not positional dizziness relieved by lying on the side.
  • • Option A. Increased intracranial pressure:
  • • Option C. Heavy meals: While heavy meals can cause discomfort, they are unlikely to cause the specific positional symptoms described.
  • • Option C. Heavy meals:
  • • Option D. Excessive venous pooling at the feet: This might cause symptoms such as swelling and discomfort in the legs but not the specific positional dizziness described.
  • • Option D. Excessive venous pooling at the feet:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inferior vena cava compression by the gravid uterus in late pregnancy can cause supine hypotensive syndrome, leading to light-headedness and dizziness when lying on the back, which is relieved by lying on the side or walking.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. She is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain. On examination, a right adnexal mass was palpable and non-tender. On ultrasound, a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary was noted. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months

options.label: B
options.text: Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan

options.label: C
options.text: Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of cyst

options.label: D
options.text: Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.correct_answer: D. Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The next best step in managing a postmenopausal woman with a small (3 x 3 cm) smooth ovarian cyst is to measure CA-125 levels. CA-125 is a tumor marker used to assess the risk of ovarian cancer, especially in postmenopausal women. Given the benign characteristics of the cyst on ultrasound and the small size, the initial step is to evaluate CA-125 levels:
  • • CA-125 Levels: If the CA-125 levels are normal (less than 35), the patient can be advised to have regular follow-ups. Regular Follow-ups: If CA-125 levels are normal, a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) should be repeated in 6-12 weeks to monitor the cyst. If the cyst persists but remains benign, yearly TVS is recommended.
  • • CA-125 Levels: If the CA-125 levels are normal (less than 35), the patient can be advised to have regular follow-ups.
  • • CA-125 Levels:
  • • Regular Follow-ups: If CA-125 levels are normal, a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) should be repeated in 6-12 weeks to monitor the cyst. If the cyst persists but remains benign, yearly TVS is recommended.
  • • Regular Follow-ups:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Reassure and advise regular follow-up once in 6 months: While reassurance is part of the management, initial evaluation with CA-125 is necessary to rule out malignancy before deciding on the follow-up schedule.
  • • Option A. Reassure and advise regular follow-up once in 6 months:
  • • Option B. Confirm USG findings by ordering a CT scan: A CT scan is not the first-line investigation for a simple cyst with benign features. Initial evaluation with CA-125 is more appropriate.
  • • Option B. Confirm USG findings by ordering a CT scan:
  • • Option C. Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of the cyst: This is invasive and not indicated for a small, benign-appearing cyst without other concerning features.
  • • Option C. Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of the cyst:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Simple cysts in the post-menopausal age grp:
  • ➤ ≤ 1cm: Considered normal ≤ 5 cm: Ca125; if normal, repeat in 6-12 weeks > 6 cm: Surgical evaluation
  • ➤ ≤ 1cm: Considered normal
  • ➤ ≤ 5 cm: Ca125; if normal, repeat in 6-12 weeks
  • ➤ > 6 cm: Surgical evaluation
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 217, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 217, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: When is dilatation and curettage contraindicated? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pelvic inflammatory disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) includes endometritis, salpingitis, oophoritis, and parametritis. Any interventions like dilatation and curettage (D&C) are contraindicated in active PID due to the risk of exacerbating the infection and causing further complications.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Ectopic pregnancy : D&C is not contraindicated in ectopic pregnancy; however, it is not typically performed in its management as it does not provide any benefit for this condition.
  • • Option B. Ectopic pregnancy
  • • Option C. Menstrual irregularities : D&C can be performed to obtain an endometrial biopsy in peri-menopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) if there are no other identifiable causes and if endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy is suspected.
  • • Option C. Menstrual irregularities
  • • Option D. Endometriosis : D&C is not usually performed solely for endometriosis unless there is an associated AUB that needs to be evaluated or treated.
  • • Option D. Endometriosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to the risk of spreading the infection
  • ➤ Ref: Page 168, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 168, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: A female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5 and there is no end-diastolic blood flow. What is the management? (INICET MAY 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Immediate termination

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The scenario described indicates fetal compromise, specifically with the findings of oligohydramnios (AFI = 5) and absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler. These are signs of severe placental insufficiency and fetal distress.
  • • Absent or Reversed End-Diastolic Flow: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound indicating severe fetal compromise. The absence of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery suggests that the fetus is not receiving adequate blood flow, leading to an increased risk of hypoxia and stillbirth. Management: Immediate Termination: For pregnancies beyond 34 weeks, immediate delivery is indicated to prevent further fetal compromise. This is because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits, given the significant risk of fetal hypoxia and potential demise.
  • • Absent or Reversed End-Diastolic Flow: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound indicating severe fetal compromise. The absence of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery suggests that the fetus is not receiving adequate blood flow, leading to an increased risk of hypoxia and stillbirth.
  • • Absent or Reversed End-Diastolic Flow:
  • • Management: Immediate Termination: For pregnancies beyond 34 weeks, immediate delivery is indicated to prevent further fetal compromise. This is because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits, given the significant risk of fetal hypoxia and potential demise.
  • • Management:
  • • Immediate Termination: For pregnancies beyond 34 weeks, immediate delivery is indicated to prevent further fetal compromise. This is because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits, given the significant risk of fetal hypoxia and potential demise.
  • • Immediate Termination: For pregnancies beyond 34 weeks, immediate delivery is indicated to prevent further fetal compromise. This is because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits, given the significant risk of fetal hypoxia and potential demise.
  • • Immediate Termination:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks: This is not appropriate because the immediate risk to the fetus requires prompt delivery.
  • • Option B. Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks:
  • • Option C. Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion: Continuous monitoring is insufficient in this scenario as the condition indicates severe fetal distress requiring urgent intervention.
  • • Option C. Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion:
  • • Option D. Terminate after 37 weeks: Waiting until 37 weeks is not appropriate due to the immediate risk of fetal compromise.
  • • Option D. Terminate after 37 weeks:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of severe fetal compromise indicated by absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler, especially beyond 34 weeks of gestation, immediate termination of the pregnancy is warranted to prevent fetal hypoxia and potential stillbirth.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2141, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2141, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: When is the quadruple marker test done? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The quadruple marker test is a prenatal screening test performed during the second trimester of pregnancy , typically between 16 and 20 weeks of gestation .
  • • prenatal screening test
  • • second trimester of pregnancy
  • • between 16 and 20 weeks of gestation
  • • This test is used to assess the risk of certain genetic disorders, including Down syndrome (trisomy 21) , trisomy 18, and neural tube defects.
  • • Down syndrome (trisomy 21)
  • • The quadruple marker test measures four specific substances in the mother's blood:
  • • Unconjugated estriol (uE3) Free beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (free beta-HCG) Inhibin A Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  • • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  • • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  • • Free beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (free beta-HCG)
  • • Free beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (free beta-HCG)
  • • Inhibin A
  • • Inhibin A
  • • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  • • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  • • These markers provide information about the likelihood of certain fetal abnormalities.
  • • Note - In the case of Down syndrome, free beta-HCG and inhibin A levels tend to be elevated, while unconjugated estriol and alpha-fetoprotein levels are typically decreased.
  • • Note -
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The quadruple marker test is conducted between 16 and 20 weeks of gestation to screen for genetic disorders such as Down syndrome, trisomy 18, and neural tube defects.

questions.text: A 39 year G2P1 presents at 18 weeks 5 days for her routine targeted fetal anomaly ultrasound. The fetal anatomy appears normal, but the cervical length is 15mm. Despite being counselled that there is no clear proven benefit for the same; the patient insisted on a cervical cerclage. Which of the following is a complete contra-indication to cerclage? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ruptured membranes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ruptured Membranes: Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe. Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.
  • • Ruptured Membranes: Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe. Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.
  • • Ruptured Membranes:
  • • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe. Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.
  • • Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cerclage. When the membranes are ruptured, there is an increased risk of infection and complications, making the procedure unsafe.
  • • Cerclage involves stitching the cervix closed to prevent premature birth, which is not advisable when the protective amniotic sac is compromised.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Positive fetal fibronectin test: A positive fetal fibronectin test indicates an increased risk of preterm labor but is not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. This test measures the presence of fetal fibronectin, a protein that acts as a "glue" during pregnancy, keeping the amniotic sac attached to the lining of the uterus.
  • • Option A. Positive fetal fibronectin test:
  • • Option B. Membranes bulging into the vagina: While bulging membranes present a high-risk situation, they are not an absolute contraindication to cerclage. In some cases, cerclage can still be performed with careful management.
  • • Option B. Membranes bulging into the vagina:
  • • Option D. Advanced maternal age: Advanced maternal age is not a contraindication to cerclage. While it may increase the overall risk profile of the pregnancy, it does not specifically contraindicate the procedure.
  • • Option D. Advanced maternal age:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ruptured membranes are a complete contraindication to cervical cerclage due to the increased risk of infection and complications.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 543, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 543, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old P1L1 with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months. What is the next best investigation to do? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) UPT

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a 28-year-old woman with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months, the first step is to rule out pregnancy. The initial investigation in this scenario should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT). This is crucial because pregnancy-related complications such as threatened abortion, incomplete abortion, or ectopic pregnancy can present with irregular bleeding. Identifying or excluding pregnancy is the most immediate concern and guides subsequent management.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. TVS (Transvaginal Ultrasound): This is a valuable tool for assessing pelvic pathology and uterine abnormalities, but it is typically done after confirming the UPT results.
  • • Option B. TVS (Transvaginal Ultrasound):
  • • Option C. Pap smear: This test is used for cervical cancer screening and is not the immediate next step in evaluating irregular bleeding when pregnancy needs to be ruled out first.
  • • Option C. Pap smear:
  • • Option D. USG abdomen: While an abdominal ultrasound can provide useful information, it is less sensitive than a transvaginal ultrasound for early pregnancy detection and pelvic pathology assessment.
  • • Option D. USG abdomen:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a reproductive-age woman with irregular bleeding, the first investigation should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT) to rule out pregnancy-related causes.

Ans. C) G2P1

questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding is done for? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6 months

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first 6 months of a baby's life. During this period, the infant receives only breast milk without any additional food or drink, not even water. Breast milk provides all the essential nutrients, antibodies, and hydration needed for optimal growth and development during these first crucial months. The World Health Organization (WHO) and other health authorities strongly advocate for exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months due to its significant health benefits for both the baby and the mother.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exclusive breastfeeding should be practiced for the first 6 months of a baby's life to ensure they receive optimal nutrition and immune support.

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 12 weeks of gestation comes to the antenatal clinic for nutritional advice. Which of the following will you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Additional 300kcal in 2nd trimester

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For a pregnant woman, additional caloric intake recommendations vary by trimester. As per Williams Obstetrics: In the first trimester, no extra calories are required. In the second trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 340 kcal per day. In the third trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 452 kcal per day. According to the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), an additional intake of 300 kcal during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy is recommended. Therefore, the recommendation of an additional 300 kcal in the second trimester is appropriate.

questions.text: The correct order of events of lactation in the puerperium are? (FMGE JANUARY 2024) Lactogenesis Mammogenesis Galactopoiesis Galactokinesis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2, 1, 4, 3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The process of lactation involves several stages, each with specific physiological changes. Understanding these stages helps in comprehending the sequence of events that occur from the preparation of the breast during pregnancy to the maintenance of milk production.
  • • 2. Mammogenesis : This is the first stage, involving the development and growth of the mammary glands in preparation for lactation. It occurs during pregnancy when the breast tissue proliferates and differentiates under the influence of hormones such as estrogen and progesterone.
  • • Mammogenesis
  • • 1. Lactogenesis : This stage refers to the initiation of milk production, which begins around the time of birth. Lactogenesis is divided into two phases:
  • • Lactogenesis
  • • Lactogenesis I: Occurs during pregnancy when the mammary gland is capable of producing some milk. Lactogenesis II: Occurs postpartum when copious milk secretion begins, typically around 2-3 days after delivery, driven by the sudden drop in progesterone and the increase in prolactin.
  • • Lactogenesis I: Occurs during pregnancy when the mammary gland is capable of producing some milk.
  • • Lactogenesis II: Occurs postpartum when copious milk secretion begins, typically around 2-3 days after delivery, driven by the sudden drop in progesterone and the increase in prolactin.
  • • 4. Galactokinesis : This stage involves the ejection or movement of milk from the alveoli to the nipple. It is facilitated by the let-down reflex, which is triggered by the hormone oxytocin. Oxytocin causes the myoepithelial cells around the alveoli to contract, expelling the milk into the ducts and out through the nipple.
  • • Galactokinesis
  • • 3. Galactopoiesis : This final stage refers to the maintenance of milk production. It is sustained by the regular removal of milk from the breast, either through breastfeeding or pumping, which maintains prolactin levels and keeps the milk supply ongoing.
  • • Galactopoiesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of events in lactation during the puerperium is: Mammogenesis (breast development), Lactogenesis (initiation of milk production), Galactokinesis (milk ejection), and Galactopoiesis (maintenance of milk production).

questions.text: A G3P2L0 presents with 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She has a history of conization being done one year ago and is currently on follow-up, with no recurrence on PAP smear. She also has the history of preterm labor at 30 and 32 weeks. What is the next step of management? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.correct_answer: A. USG to see cervical length
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) USG to see cervical length

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient has several risk factors for preterm labor, including a history of previous preterm births and cervical conization. The appropriate next step in management is to perform a transvaginal ultrasound (USG) to measure the cervical length at 11-14 weeks of gestation.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Cervical length measurement: If the cervix is found to be short (less than 2.5 cm), with or without funneling of the internal os, cervical cerclage may be indicated. Progesterone supplementation: If the cervical length is normal, the patient should be started on progesterone and serial cervical length measurements should be continued. Cervical cerclage: This is a procedure where a suture is placed around the cervix to prevent or delay preterm birth. It can be done via the vaginal route using techniques like McDonald’s or Shirodkar's. Abdominal cerclage: This is considered for patients with a prior failed vaginal cerclage.
  • • Cervical length measurement: If the cervix is found to be short (less than 2.5 cm), with or without funneling of the internal os, cervical cerclage may be indicated.
  • • Cervical length measurement:
  • • Progesterone supplementation: If the cervical length is normal, the patient should be started on progesterone and serial cervical length measurements should be continued.
  • • Progesterone supplementation:
  • • Cervical cerclage: This is a procedure where a suture is placed around the cervix to prevent or delay preterm birth. It can be done via the vaginal route using techniques like McDonald’s or Shirodkar's.
  • • Cervical cerclage:
  • • Abdominal cerclage: This is considered for patients with a prior failed vaginal cerclage.
  • • Abdominal cerclage:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cervical Cerclage: While cerclage may be necessary, it should be based on the findings of cervical length measurement. Immediate cerclage without assessment is not recommended.
  • • Option B. Cervical Cerclage:
  • • Option C. Complete Bed rest: Bed rest alone is not an effective strategy for preventing preterm labor and is not indicated without further assessment.
  • • Option C. Complete Bed rest:
  • • Option D. Abdominal cerclage: This is reserved for patients with a history of failed vaginal cerclage and is not the first-line approach.
  • • Option D. Abdominal cerclage:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with risk factors for preterm labor, including a history of cervical conization and previous preterm births, the next step is to perform a transvaginal ultrasound to measure cervical length at 11-14 weeks of gestation. Based on the findings, appropriate interventions, such as cervical cerclage or progesterone supplementation, can be considered.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg2094
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg2094

questions.text: Match the following disorders causing secondary amenorrhea with their respective lab findings: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-D, 3-C, 4-B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Secondary amenorrhea is the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses. Premature Ovarian failure: FSH and LH levels will be very high, estrogen levels are low Asherman's syndrome: As the cause in the endometrium, hormonal levels are normal. PCOS: Alteration in the LH/FSH ratio Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy: Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism: So FSH and LH are low and so is Estrogen
  • • Secondary amenorrhea is the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses.
  • • Premature Ovarian failure: FSH and LH levels will be very high, estrogen levels are low
  • • Asherman's syndrome: As the cause in the endometrium, hormonal levels are normal.
  • • PCOS: Alteration in the LH/FSH ratio
  • • Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy: Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism: So FSH and LH are low and so is Estrogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To correctly diagnose the underlying cause of secondary amenorrhea, it is essential to understand and interpret the hormonal profiles associated with different conditions:
  • ➤ Premature Ovarian Failure: Elevated FSH and LH levels with decreased estradiol indicate ovarian insufficiency. Asherman Syndrome: Low levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol suggest an endometrial cause, such as scarring. PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome): Typically characterized by normal FSH, elevated LH, and normal estradiol levels, reflecting an imbalance in gonadotropins. Sheehan Syndrome: Normal levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol are indicative of pituitary insufficiency, where the pituitary gland fails to stimulate the ovaries.

  • ➤ PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome):
  • ➤ Sheehan Syndrome: Normal levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol are indicative of pituitary insufficiency, where the pituitary gland fails to stimulate the ovaries.

questions.text: A 34 year G2P1 presents at 35 weeks. She has no complaints and is appreciating fetal movements well. She had a previous classical cesarean at 25 weeks for eclampsia and severe FGR. She is currently on low dose aspirin and prenatal vitamins. On examination, the uterus is SFH is 38 cm and FHR is 140 bpm. An ultrasound reveals a single live fetus in breech presentation, placenta posterior and amniotic fluid normal. The patient desires a vaginal delivery. What is the best management? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: D
options.text: Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version

questions.correct_answer: B. Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks: The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture. A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor. Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.
  • • Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks: The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture. A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor. Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.
  • • Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks:
  • • The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture. A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor. Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.
  • • The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture.
  • • A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor.
  • • Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Review USG after 2 weeks: This option does not address the critical issue of the patient's previous classical cesarean section, which necessitates planning for a repeat cesarean delivery.
  • • Option A. Review USG after 2 weeks:
  • • Option C. ECV at 36 weeks: External Cephalic Version (ECV) is contraindicated in patients with a previous classical cesarean section due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.
  • • Option C. ECV at 36 weeks:
  • • Option D. Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version: Awaiting spontaneous labor is not advisable due to the increased risk of uterine rupture with a classical cesarean scar. Additionally, internal podalic version is not a recommended procedure in this context.
  • • Option D. Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A classical cesarean section is an absolute contraindication to a vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture; hence, an elective cesarean section should be scheduled at 37 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct cause of maternal death? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pre-eclampsia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Maternal deaths can be classified into direct and indirect causes. Direct causes are those that result from complications of pregnancy, labor, or the postpartum period, whereas indirect causes are conditions that are exacerbated by pregnancy.
  • • Pre-eclampsia : This is a direct cause of maternal death. Pre-eclampsia is a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy that can lead to severe complications such as eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, stroke, and organ failure, all of which can directly result in maternal mortality.
  • • Pre-eclampsia
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anemia : This is considered an indirect cause of maternal death. While severe anemia can exacerbate complications during pregnancy and childbirth, it is not a direct cause but increases the risk of infections, hemorrhage, and other complications.
  • • Option A. Anemia
  • • indirect cause
  • • Option B. Heart disease : This is also an indirect cause of maternal death. Pre-existing heart disease can worsen during pregnancy due to the increased cardiovascular demands, but it is not a complication arising directly from pregnancy.
  • • Option B. Heart disease
  • • indirect cause
  • • Option C. Embolism : Pulmonary embolism is considered an indirect cause of maternal death when it occurs due to pregnancy-related factors like deep vein thrombosis.
  • • Option C. Embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pre-eclampsia is a direct cause of maternal death, directly associated with complications arising from pregnancy, labor, or the postpartum period.

questions.text: A woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation? (INICET NOV 2022) Goodell's sign Osiander's sign Internal ballottement Lightening
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Goodell's sign : This sign is the softening of the cervix, which can be elicited around the 6th week of gestation. Osiander's sign : This sign refers to the increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices, which can be detected between 6 to 8 weeks of gestation. Internal ballottement : This can be elicited between the 16th and 28th weeks of gestation when the fetus can be felt to move away and return to the fingers upon gentle tap on the cervix. Lightening : This is a sensation of relief of the pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part, typically felt around 38 weeks of gestation.
  • • Goodell's sign : This sign is the softening of the cervix, which can be elicited around the 6th week of gestation.
  • • Goodell's sign
  • • Osiander's sign : This sign refers to the increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices, which can be detected between 6 to 8 weeks of gestation.
  • • Osiander's sign
  • • Internal ballottement : This can be elicited between the 16th and 28th weeks of gestation when the fetus can be felt to move away and return to the fingers upon gentle tap on the cervix.
  • • Internal ballottement
  • • Lightening : This is a sensation of relief of the pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part, typically felt around 38 weeks of gestation.
  • • Lightening
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. 1, 3 : Internal ballottement cannot be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation as it is typically felt between 16 and 28 weeks.
  • • Option A. 1, 3
  • • Option C. 1, 4 : Lightening is not experienced until about 38 weeks of gestation, making this option incorrect.
  • • Option C. 1, 4
  • • Option D. 3, 4 : Neither internal ballottement nor lightening can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation.
  • • Option D. 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The signs that can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation are Goodell's sign (softening of the cervix) and Osiander's sign (increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices).

questions.text: Which of the following heart sounds would be normal in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During pregnancy, the cardiovascular system undergoes significant changes to accommodate the increased blood volume and cardiac output required to support both the mother and the developing fetus. One of the normal physiological changes includes the presence of the S3 heart sound.
  • • S3 Heart Sound: The S3 sound, also known as the ventricular gallop, is due to rapid diastolic filling of the ventricles. It is commonly heard in pregnant women due to the increased blood volume and cardiac output.
  • • S3 Heart Sound: The S3 sound, also known as the ventricular gallop, is due to rapid diastolic filling of the ventricles. It is commonly heard in pregnant women due to the increased blood volume and cardiac output.
  • • S3 Heart Sound:

  • • Other heart sounds mentioned are not typically considered normal in pregnancy
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. S4 Heart Sound: The S4 sound, or atrial gallop, is generally associated with pathological conditions such as left ventricular hypertrophy or myocardial ischemia. It is rare in pregnancy.
  • • Option B. S4 Heart Sound:
  • • Option C. Fixed Splitting of S2: Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is usually indicative of an atrial septal defect (ASD) and is not normal in pregnancy.
  • • Option C. Fixed Splitting of S2:
  • • Option D. Pericardial Knock: This is a sound heard in cases of constrictive pericarditis and is not a normal finding in pregnancy.
  • • Option D. Pericardial Knock:

Educational Objective:

Previously, the normal range was considered 21 to 35 days, but this has been updated to reflect a broader range of normal cycle lengths.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents in OPD with complaints of cyclical pain in abdomen. On examination, a suprapubic bulge can be seen in the pelvic area. PR examination reveals a swelling in the anterior aspect. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given case scenario points to a diagnosis of cryptomenorrhea, due to an imperforate hymen.
  • • Cryptomenorrhea is a condition in which menstruation occurs but is not visible due to obstruction of the outflow tract resulting in either hematometra (blood collection within the uterus) or hematocolpos (blood collection within vagina). In the long term, it may result in endometriosis, urinary retention and infertility.
  • • IMPERFORATE HYMEN
  • • IMPERFORATE HYMEN
  • • Presents as cryptomenorrhea H/o cyclical abdominal pain/cyclical dysmenorrhea Local examination: bluish bulge with intact hymen On P/R: swelling (hematocolpos) felt along length of vagina anteriorly Treatment: Cruciate incision.
  • • Presents as cryptomenorrhea
  • • H/o cyclical abdominal pain/cyclical dysmenorrhea
  • • Local examination: bluish bulge with intact hymen
  • • On P/R: swelling (hematocolpos) felt along length of vagina anteriorly
  • • Treatment: Cruciate incision.
  • • In Imperforate hymen, swelling is seen all along the length of the vagina on PR examination as there is hematocolpos (blood in the vagina)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Transverse vaginal septum : Transverse vaginal septum is a Müllerian anomaly. On examination, blind vagina is found. No tense blue hymen and cough impulse will be absent. Diagnosis can be confirmed by MRI
  • • Option A. Transverse vaginal septum
  • • Option B. Vaginal atresia : If vaginal introitus is not seen, then it’s vaginal atresia
  • • Option B. Vaginal atresia
  • • Option D. Cervical agenesis : Cervical agenesis will show absence of a cervix is on examination.
  • • Option D. Cervical agenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Imperforate hymen presents with cryptomenorrhea, characterized by cyclical abdominal pain and hematocolpos due to obstruction of menstrual flow, with a suprapubic bulge and anterior swelling palpable on PR examination.

questions.text: A married woman gives birth to twins. The husband doubts he is the father and gets a paternity test done. The test shows that he is the father of one infant but not the other. This is? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A case of superfecundation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Superfecundation:
  • • Superfecundation:
  • • This refers to the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different acts of intercourse, potentially involving different partners. This scenario explains how twins can have different fathers, as one ovum could be fertilized by sperm from the husband, and the other by sperm from another man.
  • • This refers to the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different acts of intercourse, potentially involving different partners.
  • • This scenario explains how twins can have different fathers, as one ovum could be fertilized by sperm from the husband, and the other by sperm from another man.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Superfetation: This refers to fertilization of two ova from different menstrual cycles. It is an extremely rare phenomenon and has never been documented in humans, though it is known to occur in some animals.
  • • Option A. Superfetation:
  • • Option B. One infant is atavistic: Atavism refers to the appearance of characteristics found in distant ancestors but not observed in recent generations. It does not apply to paternity.
  • • Option B. One infant is atavistic:
  • • Option D. One infant is suppositious : Suppositious refers to something that is fraudulently substituted. This term does not explain the situation of having different fathers for twins.
  • • Option D. One infant is suppositious

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superfecundation is the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different partners, explaining how twins can have different fathers.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. She has a positive pap smear. What is the next line of management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Colposcopy directed biopsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A positive pap smear indicates the presence of some cytological abnormality (such as epithelial or glandular cell abnormalities). The next appropriate step is to perform a colposcopy and directed biopsy. Colposcopy provides a magnified view of the cervix, allowing for the identification and biopsy of abnormal areas. During the colposcopy, scoring systems like Ried’s index or Swede’s score are used to evaluate the severity of the pathology, and cervical biopsy samples are taken from acetowhite areas identified during the procedure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cone biopsy (Conization):
  • • Option B. Cone biopsy (Conization):
  • • Conization is typically reserved for situations where there is: Unsatisfactory colposcopic findings (where the entire lesion cannot be visualized). Inconsistent findings between colposcopy, cytology, and directed biopsy. Positive endocervical curettage. When biopsy cannot rule out invasive cancer from carcinoma in situ (CIS) or microinvasion.
  • • Conization is typically reserved for situations where there is: Unsatisfactory colposcopic findings (where the entire lesion cannot be visualized). Inconsistent findings between colposcopy, cytology, and directed biopsy. Positive endocervical curettage. When biopsy cannot rule out invasive cancer from carcinoma in situ (CIS) or microinvasion.
  • • Unsatisfactory colposcopic findings (where the entire lesion cannot be visualized). Inconsistent findings between colposcopy, cytology, and directed biopsy. Positive endocervical curettage. When biopsy cannot rule out invasive cancer from carcinoma in situ (CIS) or microinvasion.
  • • Unsatisfactory colposcopic findings (where the entire lesion cannot be visualized).
  • • Inconsistent findings between colposcopy, cytology, and directed biopsy.
  • • Positive endocervical curettage.
  • • When biopsy cannot rule out invasive cancer from carcinoma in situ (CIS) or microinvasion.
  • • Option C. Repeat pap smear:
  • • Option C. Repeat pap smear:
  • • This is not preferred in this scenario as the exact abnormality on the pap smear is not specified. In cases of low-grade squamous intra-epithelial lesion (LSIL) with negative HPV, a repeat pap smear with HPV testing may be advised, but this is not applicable here.
  • • This is not preferred in this scenario as the exact abnormality on the pap smear is not specified. In cases of low-grade squamous intra-epithelial lesion (LSIL) with negative HPV, a repeat pap smear with HPV testing may be advised, but this is not applicable here.
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy:
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy:
  • • Hysterectomy is never indicated solely for an abnormal pap smear. It is considered only if the colposcopic-directed biopsy shows: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) associated with other gynecologic problems such as prolapse, fibroids, pelvic inflammatory disease, or endometriosis. Persistent dyskaryotic smear despite treatment. High-grade CIN in elderly women. Patients with poor compliance for follow-up.

It is considered only if the colposcopic-directed biopsy shows: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) associated with other gynecologic problems such as prolapse, fibroids, pelvic inflammatory disease, or endometriosis. Persistent dyskaryotic smear despite treatment. High-grade CIN in elderly women. Patients with poor compliance for follow-up.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy. When will the final switch to heparin be advised? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 36 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The management of anticoagulation in pregnant women with cardiac disease involves switching from warfarin to heparin at specific times to minimize the risk of complications to the fetus and to prepare for delivery.
  • • Switch to Heparin at 36 Weeks: According to guidelines from the American College of Chest Physicians, pregnant women on warfarin therapy should switch to heparin at 36 weeks of gestation. This is done to reduce the risk of bleeding complications during labor and delivery.
  • • Switch to Heparin at 36 Weeks: According to guidelines from the American College of Chest Physicians, pregnant women on warfarin therapy should switch to heparin at 36 weeks of gestation. This is done to reduce the risk of bleeding complications during labor and delivery.
  • • Switch to Heparin at 36 Weeks:
  • • Guidelines Summary:
  • • Guidelines Summary:
  • • Early Pregnancy (up to 12 weeks): Discontinue warfarin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed, especially if the warfarin dose is >5mg/day, due to the risk of warfarin embryopathy. Replace with heparin (5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously) or low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). After 12 Weeks to 36 Weeks: Warfarin can be resumed after the 12th week and continued up to 36 weeks. At 36 Weeks: Switch from warfarin to heparin (either unfractionated or LMWH). Just Before Delivery: Discontinue heparin just before delivery. Postpartum: Restart heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after cesarean section. Warfarin therapy can also be safely resumed during breastfeeding.

questions.text: A teenage girl presented with irregular cycles and increased facial hair. Her ovaries showed increased volume. Which of the following are used in the first line treatment? (INICET MAY 2021) Laparoscopic ovarian drilling Anti-androgens Lifestyle modifications Combined oral contraceptive pills
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of irregular menstrual cycles and increased facial hair, combined with increased ovarian volume, is suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) . The first-line treatment options for PCOS typically include:
  • • polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
  • • Anti-androgens (2): These medications help reduce symptoms related to excess androgens, such as facial hair and acne. Common examples include spironolactone.
  • • Anti-androgens
  • • Lifestyle modifications (3): These are crucial for managing PCOS. Weight loss and exercise can improve insulin sensitivity and help regulate menstrual cycles.
  • • Lifestyle modifications
  • • Combined oral contraceptive pills (4): These are used to regulate menstrual cycles, reduce hyperandrogenism symptoms (like hirsutism), and provide endometrial protection.
  • • Combined oral contraceptive pills
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Laparoscopic ovarian drilling (1): This is a surgical procedure used to treat PCOS, but it is generally considered a second-line treatment. It is typically performed when medical management fails to achieve the desired results.
  • • Laparoscopic ovarian drilling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line treatments for PCOS include anti-androgens, lifestyle modifications, and combined oral contraceptive pills.

questions.text: Which of the following drug must always be available for emergency use in labor ward if a patient is on opioid analgesic? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Naloxone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Naloxone is a narcotic antagonist capable of reversing respiratory depression induced by opioid narcotics. It acts by displacing the narcotic from specific receptors in the central nervous system, thus reversing the effects of the opioid, including respiratory depression. This makes it an essential drug to have on hand in the labor ward when a patient is receiving opioid analgesics.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Fentanyl: This is an opioid analgesic used for pain management, not for reversing opioid effects.
  • • Option A. Fentanyl:
  • • Option C. Morphine: This is another opioid analgesic and would not be used to counteract the effects of other opioids.
  • • Option C. Morphine:
  • • Option D. Bupivacaine: This is a local anesthetic used for epidural anesthesia, not an opioid antagonist.
  • • Option D. Bupivacaine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Naloxone must always be available in the labor ward for emergency use when a patient is on opioid analgesic to promptly reverse opioid-induced respiratory depression.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came for routine PAP smear testing. The report came as carcinoma in situ. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Conization

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix is classified as Stage 0 cancer. In a young woman with stage 0 cervical cancer, the management of choice is conization. Conization involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix, including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix. This procedure serves both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes:
  • • Diagnostic: Conization provides a tissue specimen for histopathological examination, which is more definitive compared to a cytological specimen obtained from a Pap smear. Therapeutic: If the histopathology shows clear margins, conization can be curative for carcinoma in situ.
  • • Diagnostic: Conization provides a tissue specimen for histopathological examination, which is more definitive compared to a cytological specimen obtained from a Pap smear.
  • • Diagnostic:
  • • Therapeutic: If the histopathology shows clear margins, conization can be curative for carcinoma in situ.
  • • Therapeutic:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Hysterectomy: This is a more radical treatment and is generally reserved for cases where there is invasive cancer or other indications. It is not the first-line treatment for CIS in a young woman.
  • • Option B. Hysterectomy:
  • • Option C. Colposcopy and biopsy: While colposcopy and biopsy are diagnostic procedures used to evaluate abnormal Pap smears, in the case of confirmed carcinoma in situ, conization is preferred as it provides both a diagnosis and potential cure.
  • • Option C. Colposcopy and biopsy:
  • • Option D. HPV DNA testing: This test is used for screening and risk assessment but is not a treatment for confirmed carcinoma in situ.
  • • Option D. HPV DNA testing:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conization, which involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix, is the management of choice for carcinoma in situ in young women. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic if histopathology shows clear margins.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 992, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 992, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following complication is specific to Monochorionic twins? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.correct_answer: C. Twin to twin transfusion syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Complications specific to monochorionic twins are:
  • • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) : This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels. TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion) : This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.
  • • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) : This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels.
  • • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion) : This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.
  • • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction : While this can occur in monochorionic twins, it is not specific to them.
  • • Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction
  • • Option B. Polyhydramnios : This can be seen in various conditions and is not specific to monochorionic twins.
  • • Option B. Polyhydramnios
  • • Option D. Neural tube defects : These can occur in any pregnancy and are not specific to monochorionic twins.
  • • Option D. Neural tube defects
  • • Thus, options A, B, and D are not specific complications of monochorionic twins.
  • • Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg904,905
  • • Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg904,905

questions.text: A primigravida presented to the labor room at 38 weeks. At 1 pm she is 5 cm dilated. After 4 hours she is 6 cm dilated. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ARM + oxytocin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient is experiencing protracted labor, as indicated by a slow progression in cervical dilation (only 1 cm increase in 4 hours). In active labor, the cervix is expected to dilate at a rate of approximately 1 cm per hour. Here, the cervix dilated from 5 cm to 6 cm in 4 hours, indicating a slow or protracted dilation phase.
  • • slow or protracted dilation phase.
  • • Management of Protracted Labor:
  • • Assessment: Evaluate the cause of slow labor, which could be due to issues with powers (uterine contractions), the passage (pelvis), or the passenger (fetal position or presentation).
  • • powers (uterine contractions), the passage (pelvis), or the passenger (fetal position or presentation).
  • • Augmentation of Labor:
  • • Augmentation of Labor:
  • • 1 st step: ARM (Artificial Rupture of Membranes): This can help enhance uterine contractions and allow assessment of the amniotic fluid for the presence of meconium, which could indicate fetal distress. 2 nd step: Oxytocin: If contractions remain inadequate after ARM, oxytocin can be administered to strengthen uterine contractions and accelerate labor progress.
  • • 1 st step: ARM (Artificial Rupture of Membranes): This can help enhance uterine contractions and allow assessment of the amniotic fluid for the presence of meconium, which could indicate fetal distress.
  • • 2 nd step: Oxytocin: If contractions remain inadequate after ARM, oxytocin can be administered to strengthen uterine contractions and accelerate labor progress.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Wait for 4 hours and reexamine: This is not recommended as it allows prolonged labor to continue without intervention, increasing the risk of complications.
  • • Option A. Wait for 4 hours and reexamine:
  • • Option B. LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section): While a cesarean section may be necessary if augmentation fails or if there are other indications, it is not the immediate next step without attempting augmentation.
  • • Option B. LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section):
  • • Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps can only be applied when the cervix is fully dilated (10 cm), not at 6 cm.
  • • Option D. Forceps delivery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a primigravida with protracted labor (slow cervical dilation), the next best step is to perform artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and administer oxytocin to augment labor and promote adequate uterine contractions.

questions.text: Patient came to the emergency department with 32 weeks of pregnancy with pedal edema and BP of 140/90 mmHg. Urine dipstick was 2+. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Preeclampsia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with symptoms that align with the diagnosis of preeclampsia, which is characterized by the following criteria:
  • • Elevated blood pressure (≥140/90 mmHg) after 20 weeks of gestation. Proteinuria (≥1+ on dipstick or 300 mg/24 hours).
  • • Elevated blood pressure (≥140/90 mmHg) after 20 weeks of gestation.
  • • after 20 weeks of gestation.
  • • Proteinuria (≥1+ on dipstick or 300 mg/24 hours).
  • • In this case, the patient has a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and a urine dipstick showing 2+ proteinuria, which fits the criteria for preeclampsia. The presence of pedal edema further supports this diagnosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Abruption : This typically presents with painful vaginal bleeding and uterine tenderness. While preeclampsia can be a risk factor for abruption, the absence of vaginal bleeding in this case makes abruption less likely.
  • • Option B. Abruption
  • • Option C. PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) : This occurs after delivery and is characterized by significant bleeding post-delivery, which is not relevant in this antepartum scenario.
  • • Option C. PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage)
  • • Option D. Gestational Hypertension : This is characterized by elevated blood pressure without proteinuria or other signs of preeclampsia. The presence of proteinuria in this patient rules out gestational hypertension.
  • • Option D. Gestational Hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Preeclampsia is diagnosed in pregnant patients presenting with hypertension and proteinuria after 20 weeks of gestation. This condition requires careful monitoring and management to prevent complications for both the mother and the fetus.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lactating female with an 18-month-old child comes with a history of irregular, heavy bleeding seeking contraceptive advice. Which is the contraceptive of choice? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mala N

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mala N : Among the given options, Mala N, a combined oral contraceptive pill, is the contraceptive of choice for this lactating woman. It will help regulate her cycles and reduce the menstrual flow. Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) are contraindicated in breastfeeding mothers for the first 6 months postpartum due to potential effects on milk production. However, after 6 months, they can be safely used.

It will help regulate her cycles and reduce the menstrual flow. Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) are contraindicated in breastfeeding mothers for the first 6 months postpartum due to potential effects on milk production. However, after 6 months, they can be safely used.

Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) are contraindicated in breastfeeding mothers for the first 6 months postpartum due to potential effects on milk production. However, after 6 months, they can be safely used.
  • • Among the given options, Mala N, a combined oral contraceptive pill, is the contraceptive of choice for this lactating woman. It will help regulate her cycles and reduce the menstrual flow.
  • • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) are contraindicated in breastfeeding mothers for the first 6 months postpartum due to potential effects on milk production. However, after 6 months, they can be safely used.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Progestasert : Progestasert is a progesterone-releasing intrauterine device. Progesterone-containing contraceptives can cause irregular bleeding, which is not desirable for this patient who already has irregular and heavy bleeding.
  • • Option A. Progestasert
  • • Option B. Copper-T 380A : Copper-T 380A is a non-hormonal intrauterine device that may exacerbate heavy menstrual bleeding and would not be suitable for a patient already experiencing heavy bleeding.
  • • Option B. Copper-T 380A
  • • Option D. Norethisterone enanthate - depot injection : Norethisterone enanthate is a progesterone-only injectable contraceptive. Progesterone-only contraceptives can cause irregular bleeding, making it an unsuitable choice for this patient with irregular heavy bleeding.
  • • Option D. Norethisterone enanthate - depot injection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a lactating woman with a history of irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding, a combined oral contraceptive pill (COC) like Mala N is the preferred choice after the first 6 months postpartum as it helps regulate menstrual cycles and reduce menstrual flow.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 398, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7 th edition

questions.text: A 16-year-old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and Tanner grade 1 breast development. USG shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows raised FSH, raised LH, and reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome is characterized by primary amenorrhea, streak ovaries, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, widely spaced nipples, and a webbed neck.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3 rd edition pg411, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 441
